title: universal credit couple car cold years house
story: A DESPERATE couple who have been forced to live in their Mercedes say their situation is so dire that they could be dead before they get housed.Tina and Winston Reid, both , who have been homeless for eight weeks and depend on Universal Credit, were told by council bosses that they could be waiting for two years for a home.The pair previously rented a privately-owned house in Romford, Essex, for four years.But they had to leave after their landlord decided to sell the property.They initially bought a caravan in Thurrock and lived in that for two years.But then eight weeks ago disaster struck when the the caravan had a sewage problem which drove them on the street.Since then the couple have been braving the cold conditions living in former bricklayer Winstons Mercedes on Mersea Island.The unbearable living conditions have led Tina to attempt suicide and it has wreaked havoc with Winstons preexisting back issues.They have met a brick wall with their requests for temporary housing and with more cold weather coming, they are worried they may die this winter.Tina said: Thurrock Council told us they were unable to find housing for us as we havent been living there long enough.The couple ended up driving to picturesque Mersea so Tina could be closer to her parents.My dad has dementia and my mum uses a walking stick - they live in a one-bed flat so there is no room for us there.Colchester Council said it would assist me in finding private housing.I have called around  houses but they wont take us as we dont have a guarantor and they ask for so much money upfront.Im on Employment Support Allowance and my husband is on Universal Credit, and we have to use that money to stay in rooms for a night where we can, just to get out of the cold, she added.Tina has been sleeping in the back of the Mercedes, while Winston takes the front seat.We have both been to AE recently. I was there because I tried to take my own le, I couldnt take it any more.My husband was there because of his back, its painful being in the car.One million people are already receiving it and by the time the system is fully rolled out in , nearly  million will be on it.But there are big problems with the flagship new system - it takes  weeks to get the first payment and it could leave some families worse off by thousands of pounds a year.And while working families can claim back up to  per cent of their childcare costs, they must find the money to pay for childcare upfront - we’ve heard of families waiting up to  months for the money.Working parents across the country told us they’ve been unable to take on more hours - or have even turned down better paid jobs or more hours because of the amount they get their benefits cut.It’s time to Make Universal Credit work. We want the government to:Together, these changes will help Make Universal Credit Work.Join our Universal Credit Facebook group or email UniversalCredit@the-sun to share your story. Winston is  this year and when you reach  youre entitled to sheltered housing.However his birthday is in May and we could be dead by then. Im worried we are going to die here.Universal Credit is the Governments new flagship benefits system, but it has been slammed by charities and claimants who say it is pushing more people into poverty.Currently it takes five weeks to get the first payment, leaving many people in insurmountable debt, and working families have to pay childcare costs upfront, before later claiming back  per cent of the cost.The Sun is campaigning for the Work Allowance to be raised and the taper rate reduced to p for every £ earned to help at least four million families hold on to their hard earned cash.A spokesman for Colchester Borough Homes warned could take up to two years for some people to get a home.As a general rule this meansany applicant presents as homeless and we believe they may have a priority need, we may have a duty to provide accommodation while we look to find a housing solution that relieves their homelessness.If we do not believe they have a priority need, accommodation will not be provided but we will still assist them to secure alternative accommodation.If we are unable to relieve their homelessness, we are required to make inquiries under the full or main homeless duty.If we accept this duty, temporary accommodation will be provided and their banding on the housing register will be amended to reflect this.Applicants will then remain in temporary accommodation until they are either housed through the housing register or we end the duty by placing them in private sector accommodation.It is dficult to determine theof time an applicant will have to wait for specic property types to become available, as applicants are able to decide this by bidding on properties.In general, most applicants wait in excess of  to  months.

title: dover python loose snake spotted back garden
story: The monster serpent was spotted slithering under a fence and into an alley between houses in Kent on Monday night.Local resident Mark Smith, , who owns two giant Burmese pythons, was notied of the escaped animal when his friend called him to say hed seen a snakes head pop out under a fence while he was walking home.Snake-loving Smith, whose pets were safely locked away when the escaped reptile was sighted, then went out looking for it and posted about the incident on Facebook.But the python still hasnt been found.Smith told Kent Live: I got over there just before midnight to look for it. I knocked on the houses and there but there was no answer. A couple of cats seemed a bit skitty.Now its so cold, snakes usually find somewhere warm like a shed. My phone had nearly died and it got really cold so I went back home.Mark went around houses in the area just before midnight knocking on doors, but no one answered and the snake was nowhere to be seen.The next day, the petried owner of the house where the snake had been seen saw Marks Facebook post and contacted him.But the pair were unable to track it down with Mark worrying someone may have kept the animal for themselves as they can be worth up to £.The RSPCA contacted Mark to tell him not to engage with the snakehe found it, but rather contact them so they can take it to the vets.They havent been contacted about any further sightings, however, as locals are becoming increasingly worried about its whereabouts.Mark added: The snakes not really dangerous, its just trying to find somewhere warm but people are scared of it.

title: prince philip continued driving hip replacement retiring
story: The Duke of Edinburgh, , miraculously walked away from a dramatic crash yesterday near Sandringham, which left his x overturned.Weeks after his hip operation last April he was photographed behind the wheel of his Land Rover appearing in good spirits at the Royal Windsor Horse Show.Looking extremely comfortable in the drivers seat, he even briefly stopped to speak to the Queen through his window.And he continued to defy expectations when he was seen travelling with the Queen in the royal Bentley to a church service in August.Prince Charles had previously told of his concern about his dads getting behind the wheel.Did you see what happened  Were you involved  Contact The Sun Online brittany.vonow@the-sun or call   . You can WhatsApp us on   .In June  the Prince of Wales told a D-Day veterans son he was worried about the fact the Duke was still driving a car.Charles was speaking to Ivor Thomas, a former Corporal in the Royal Engineers, who was with his wheelchair-bound dad who was still driving a  Ford Sierra.So does my father. Im always worried, Charles said, before gesturing towards Mr Thomas, and asking: But his eyesights all right But the fiercely independent royal was left shocked and very, very shaken following a dramatic crash near Sandringham.Eyewitnesses reported seeing his Land Rover flip over onto the drivers door.The Duke was pulling out of a driveway onto the A at Babingley when his car was smashed on its side.Philip - who miraculously walked away from the crash - is now being cared for by royal doctors and the Queen is by his side at Sandringham.The Prince made it clear that his retirement from royal duties after  years in the public eye was not due to health reasons, but so he could have more leisure time.A few days after Buckingham Palace announced his retirement, the Duke, then , was out and about carriage driving at the Royal Windsor Horse Show.He has even continued to enjoy carriage driving, which has been one of his favourite hobbies since the s.Days before Christmas he was full of festive cheer as he drove a carriage out in Windsor Castles grounds.But last month he sparked health fears as did not attend the traditional Christmas Day service for the first time.Back in , the Prince hinted after he retired from competitive carriage racing he would drive around the countryside.In his book,  Years On and Off The Box Seat, the Prince wrote: You may well wonder why I have continued to compete for quite so many years.Sales director Pat Daynes, whose car had £, of damage, said: “I was leading a normal le. Then whack, I’m part of a royal soap opera.”The simple answer is that I have enjoyed every moment of it, or, more accurately, almost every moment of it. It gets me into the fresh air and it keeps me reasonably fit.I suppose I could just drive about the country but the challenge of the competition is a great inducement to get out and practise, even when the weather conditions might be a bit discouraging.Although the Prince faced a number of health scares beyond the age of , he continued to stay behind the wheel.He even drove Barack Obama around when the then US President came to visit in April .Abdominal surgery, bladder infections and a blocked coronary artery have seen him admitted to hospital on a number of occasions.Concerns were expressed for Philips health when he appeared to lean against a pillar for support while standing during the Whitehall service.But a week later he was carriage driving at Windsor on the day of his platinum wedding anniversary, and he and the Queen celebrated in the evening with a party for more than  family and friends.And this summer break he made a remarkable bounce back to health when he was seen fishing and hunting.In September the Prince was last seen taking his Land Rover out for a spin near Balmoral in September.Donning a pair of trusty spectacles, the -year-old drove alone on the A Braemar while on his way back to Balmoral Castle.Royal biographer Hugo Vickers told BBC News: Any kind of car accident at the age of  is likely to produce shock.Some years ago he gave up flying planes long before he needed to because he was scared thatsomething happened there would be a lot of criticism.You know, why was he, at the age of , still flying a plane when he should have retired at  or something like that.So he does listen to these things - hes very, very sensible.If anyones involved in a car accident, its quite a frightening thing. If he thought that hed lost concentration or something or he hadnt seen somebody he would realise hes not up to it anymore.After his decision to retire, the younger members of the Royal family vowed to rally around and support the Queen.Prince Philip completed , solo engagements at home and abroad after he assumed his title in .When the Obamas visited the UK for a state visit in , they werent escorted from their helicopter by a security driver.Instead, the task fell to Prince Philip - a keen motorist.Mr Obama was complimentary about the dukes driving skills, and said at the time: I have to say I have never been driven by a Duke of Edinburgh before and I can report that it was very smooth riding.

title: theresa theres jeremy corbyn ira hamas hezbollah jihadis stalinists holocaust deniers
story: He was happy to talk to Hamas and Hezbollah without preconditions. He is happy to hang around with Stalinists and anti-Semites, Holocaust deniers and apologists for terrorism. But he won’t talk to the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.The Labour leader’s refusal to discuss Brexit with his Tory — and come to that, Lib Dem, SNP, DUP and Plaid Cymru — counterparts reveals the utter smallness of the man.For two years, Jezza has been noisily demanding that Theresa May “reach out” to other parties. Yet the moment she does, he comes over all snooty and stand-offish.He won’t join any discussions about our EU policy unless and until the PM pledges that we won’t leave without a deal.That condition is absurd. Mrs May, as Corbyn well knows, is also keen to avoid No Deal. But the only way to avoid that is to agree on, you know, a deal.That’s precisely why the PM is talking to the other party leaders.The only effect of publicly ruling out No Deal — as several MPs in all parties have been pompously doing — is to encourage Brussels to dig in and thus, paradoxically, to make No Deal more likely.What explains Jezza’s sudden coolness  Is it simple tribalism of the sort that has now taken over the top ranks of Labour Immediately before the vote, for example, Richard Burgon, the Corbynite Shadow Justice Secretary, repeatedly described Conservatives on TV as “the real enemy”.After the confidence motion, another Labour MP, Danielle Rowley, posted a picture of the Conservative benches with the caption, “People are dying because of these people”.Is Corbs unwilling to talk to Tories because he sees them as evil murderers I don’t think so. Part of the old booby’s schtick is that he will talk to anyone. It’s how he justies his meetings with Irish Republicans and jihadi extremists.It’s how he justies taking money to appear on a TV station backed by the ayatollahs in Tehran.He has even said that he would be prepared to negotiate with the head-hackers of IS in order to facilitate peace.I don’t think so. Part of the old booby’s schtick is that he will talk to anyone. It’s how he justies his meetings with Irish Republicans and jihadi extremists.It’s how he justies taking money to appear on a TV station backed by the ayatollahs in Tehran.He has even said that he would be prepared to negotiate with the head-hackers of IS in order to facilitate peace.No, there is a much simpler explanation for why he won’t talk to the PM. It would force him to take a public position on Brexit. And that is the last thing he wants to do.Corbyn is an Old Left Eurosceptic. He took what was, effectively, the Moscow line during the Cold War, namely that the EEC was the economic arm of Nato.He disliked what he saw as its capitalism, and knows he will be able to implement a far more radical form of socialism once Britain is no longer constrained by EU rules on competition and state aid.He also knows that the overwhelming majority of Labour MPs want to stay in the EU.During the referendum campaign, he reluctantly went along with his party, though he made little secret of his distaste.Although we’ll never know for sure, I have a strong suspicion, looking at his face as he left the polling station, that he secretly voted Leave.Be that as it may, he has since kept the Labour coalition together by attacking the Government while saying nothing about what he would do.That ambiguity has allowed him to appease his party without alienating the millions in Labour’s northern heartlands who voted Leave.From a self-interest point of view, it made sense. But the impact on Britain’s negotiating position was dire.Labour’s tactic has been to demand impossible conditions from the Government. As Barry Gardiner, the Shadow Trade Minister, was overheard saying in Brussels: “It’s bollocks — always has been bollocks.”The trouble is, that by adopting its testicular conditions, Labour has ended up arguing for something that would represent the worst of all worlds.The main stated dference between the two parties is over the customs union. Labour says it wants Brussels to control Britain’s trade policy in perpetuity after we leave.As recently as last year, Corbyn was against the customs union on the unarguable grounds that “It is protectionist against third- world countries”.That was the reason successive Labour Eurosceptics, as far back as Clement Attlee, opposed joining the EEC.But last February, spotting an opportunity to vote against the Government without having to commit to anything, Labour somersaulted and started demanding customs union membership.Be clear: Being outside the EU but inside its customs union would be disastrous. It would keep the costs of membership without the benefits of leaving.As former Canadian PM Stephen Harper, a massive Anglophile and a Remain supporter in , put it recently: “It is really critical that this country rediscovers itself as a trading nation. If you do not do that, then frankly the Brexit experience will be bad.” When I put that point to another member of the shadow cabinet in a BBC green room, he looked at me asI was mad. We’re this close to the first truly socialist government in Britain,” he told me. “You really think we care about the customs union either way ”Yet it is precisely that cynicism that voters are turning against. People are furious at the game-playing in Westminster. They accept that MPs have dfering views, but they can tell when a party is advancing bogus arguments for purely selfish reasons.In the last analysis, Jeremy Corbyn has shown himself to be unwilling to work in what he himself sees as the national interest. That is what makes him unfit for office.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: simon dobbin transformed diy sos
story: The dad-of-three was left permanently brain damaged and unable to walk or talk after being kicked, punched and pelted with glass bottles as he lay defenceless on the floor.After his brave we Nicole decided to care for him at home, DIY SOS came to their aid to ensure he would be as comfortable as possible.Presenter Nick Knowles said he wanted to transform their home so it better suited his needs – but he admitted it was a challenge.Hundreds of volunteers helped renovate the Dobbins family home in November  so the space worked for the whole family, including -year-old daughter Emily.Nicole said: “The changes that DIY SOS made to the house have made le so much easier for all of us.“Simon was originally living in the dining room and he didn’t have his own space or his own privacy and we would have to bring a bowl of water to him in bed to wash him.“Now he has his own bedroom where the living room was. He’s also got his own wet room which is more private so he can keep his dignity.“They’ve installed CCTV and a monitor in Simon’s room so I can check on him.“The monitor means I can hear him breathing and it’s like he’s next to me. It means that I don’t have to constantly be by his side to know he’s okay.“The doorways and the front door have been widened so it’s easier to get Simon from one room to the other in his wheelchair.“Before we had a manual hoist but now we have a ceiling hoist that he can use to get from his bedroom to his en-suite.She told the BBC One show: Youve really changed our lives... there are no words, what youve done is amazing.Since the vicious attack in ,  men have been convicted for their part in the assault and while they may be behind bars, the nightmare for Simon and his family goes on.His we has slammed the so called “firm” that left her husband with a “le sentence”.Nicole blasted the hooligans who “ambushed” Simon on an away day, labelling them “absolutely pathetic”.Speaking exclusively to Sun Online Nicole, , said: “Simon had always been a football fan – he would watch all the World Cups and would go to Cambridge as they are our local team.“I had seen hooligans on the news – but that was always at the really big games.“Then I found out about the firms. I just do not understand how grown men can arrange to meet each other and then kick the living daylights out of each. It is absolutely pathetic. They need to grow up. You don’t get it in any other sports.“Simon had not been involved in any trouble. They were ambushed.“Simon was just a normal, family man who went to a football match and had his le destroyed.“If we can stop just one person from joining a group then something has come out of it. Come and spend a day with my husband. I am sure that will change their minds.”Cambridge United fan Simon suffered permanent and le-changing brain damage after he was set upon as he walked to Prittlewell station in Southend, Essex.He had just watched his team in an - away draw with Southend United on March,  .The thugs convicted over the unprovoked, savage attack were handed jail terms totalling more than  years.Basildon Crown Court convicted  of their involvement in the attack.The defendants scouted out locations as they planned the attack in revenge for a fight earlier in the day in which Mr Dobbin had no involvement.They ambushed the small group of Cambridge United supporters and during the violence, Mr Dobbin, from Mildenhall, Suffolk, was kicked and stamped on repeatedly.Police called Simon “a thoroughly decent man” who was the “entirely innocent victim of an unprovoked, savage attack”.Nicole – who is now a full time carer to her husband of nearly  years – is campaigning for tougher laws for those involved football violence.Her husband had deliberately not worn football colours as “he didn’t want any trouble and didn’t want to stand out”.She said: “It was dficult for the police to pin point exactly who did what. I think thatyou are involved then you should face the maximum penalty.“Hopefully then these people would start talking as I certainly wouldn’t want to take the blame for something I didn’t do.“I knew it had been a football related. But when we had to listen to how they attacked him when he was down on the ground – that was really hard to hear.“They left him with a calling card – I actually gasped out loud when I heard details of that.”It read: Congratulations. Youve just met the CS CrewFirst we take your le, then we take your we.In a statement read to court Nicole said: “I told him to enjoy the day but this was the last time I would see the husband I married.”She added: “Police told me my husband had been attacked. The first thing I said was ‘is he dead ’“They told me he was on le support and it was serious.“We were taken to the critical care unit. I could not believe what I was seeing. His face was swollen, you couldn’t see his ear, he had tubes and wires everywhere.“He went into cardiac arrest for seven minutes at the scene.“Now Simon cannot communicate very well. He never says no. He will only say yes. He has to be fed by a tube and needs  hour care, he is prone to choking.“He will never get his le back. I have to do things for Simon that no we should do – and at such a young age.“I try not  to look back at how things were before because it just upsets me.“But there are still signs of him there – it is like he is trapped inside his body. He still has his cheekiness and his sense of humour.”The men were found guilty following a six-week trial at Basildon Crown Court after jurors delivered unanimous verdicts on all but one defendant.Eight men were found to have been directly involved in the violent disorder, while three were involved in a conspiracy.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: leaver mps no deal brexit
story: It’s not just that opting to Remain instead of Leave as the default on March  betrays the referendum result.It’s that we will have fallen into Brussels’ trap and lost their game of chicken.The surest route out of all this chaos is to win the support of the DUP and Tory Brexiteers for Theresa May’s deal.It has other flaws, but the Irish backstop is fatal — iding Britain from Northern Ireland and crushing our ambitions for independent global trade.Our dismal Chancellor Philip ­Hammond, a politician with zero drive, optimism or negotiating acumen, feebly moans it is a “waste of time” demanding from Brussels a time-limit on the backstop or an exit from it.That is typical defeatism from a man who has done everything to nully Brexit and minimise vital No Deal preparations.It is very far from a waste of time.The EU now have every incentive to make their deal with Mrs May work — but onlyNo Deal is our fallback.Why  Because the eurozone is in huge trouble.Germany is almost in recession. Its giant firms admit they are “staring into the abyss” of a No Deal. Ireland would be severely hit.If we kill that possibility off,we tell them that we’ll effectively Remain by default, that’s it: We lose.That’s why Remainers, from Nick Boles to Hammond himself, are so keen on it.Corbyn is too because he is paralysed by indecision and just needs something to say.But the Cabinet and those MPs, Tory and Labour, who know Brexit must happen need to wake up right now.They are being played like fiddles by Brussels, aided by Parliament’s Remainers and a Commons Speaker gone rogue.They must not cave in. They must fight — or the public will never forgive them.IS anyone seriously looking for a “consensus” on Brexit What concessions have any opposition leaders offered Theresa May  They all just demand a second referendum and or No Deal “taken off the table”.Yes, the Government is sticking to its guns too. But there’s a dference:IN case there was any doubt about the nauseating Remain bias of Commons Speaker John Bercow, his new accolade extinguishes it.The continental Press have named the pompous little toad “European of the Week”.How proud he must be.Let’s hope his local Tories speed up their plans to oust him as an MP.He is not the gatekeeper of our democracy. title: michael schumacher latest different in private manager reveals
story: The stricken F legend, currently being cared for at home in Switzerland following a skiing tragedy in , was known for his cold and analytical approach to winning.But behind close doors, Schuey, who turned  earlier this month, was much more relaxed.In a rare insight, Michaels manager and family friend Sabine Kehm has told how the ruthless racing ace cut a far more laid-back figure among pals.She said he was known for his infectious smile and jokey nature - and would often be seen with a rum and coke in his hands while playing football with friends.Speaking to Beyond The Grid, Forumla Ones official podcast, Sabine said Michael was privately completely dferent to his colder and more calculated public persona.She said Michael was “very relaxed” and “not so methodical” in his personal le compared with the clinical mindset he needed to succeed behind the wheel.Sabine added that the seven-time world champ was one who could enjoy his le, who had a lot of fun and spent a lot of time with friends doing things that he could laugh about afterwards.In his private sphere, he was much slower in everything he did.In Formula One everything had to be done super fast, boom, boom.Sometimes we had crazy schedules with two-minute appointments, but privately he was totally dferent, relaxed.Michael has not been seen publicly since suffering a severe brain injury in a horror skiing accident in the Alps in .Details on his condition have remained scarce.Asked about how the former racer would escape the intense demands of his career and world-famous celebrity, Kehm said: Michael clearly had his family.Corinna [and Michael] they were such a perfect couple and they are still a perfect coupleyou ask me.When he went home and the kids would come in, Formula One was far away. title: sas hero kenya hotel massacre flees face revealed social media
story: The Sun exclusively revealed how the off-duty elite soldier was in the country to train Special Forces when news broke of the gun and grenade atrocity at the DusitD hotel in Nairobi that killed  people.After getting kitted out, dramatic photos show the hero leading the charge into a building in Nairobi to free cowering locals during the terror siege.In another, the balaclava-clad elite soldier - whose face we masked - helps to carry an injured victim. His safety is paramount.He is a decorated, veteran member of the SAS who was a member of D Squadron and extremely active in Syria taking part in a number of successful operations against ISIS.He had transferred to B squadron for this assignment.The Ministry of Defence has told The Sun it does not comment on Special Forces operations.Earlier this week, an insider told The Sun: “He was training Kenyan forces when the shout went up, so he went in.“British Special Forces always run towards the sound of gunfire.“He fired off rounds during the operation. It’s a safe bet he hit his target — the SAS don’t miss. story: Residents and tourists reported feeling the tremor just after .am - after two smaller shakes went unnoticed in the early hours.One wrote on social media: Has there been an earthquake on Tenere  What a scare!Another said: Earthquake in the centre of Tenere!The National Geographic Institute confirmed the earthquake occurred at .am at a depth of five kilometres and added that a seismic movement of magnitude . on the Richter scale was registered in the same place a minute earlier.After the first one,  calls were received from people living in the Tenere municipalities of La Matanza, Tacoronte, La Laguna, Güímar, Santa Cruz de Tenere, Candelaria, Fasnia, Arico and Granadilla, all of which are in the north of the island and not the main tourist zones.Two other seismic movements were also recorded, one of them at . hours and of magnitude ., and another at . and of magnitude ..The Canary Islands volcanology institute, Involcan, said it was normal that such seismic activity would be occurring now and in the future.The organisation said this morning: All the stations of the Canary Seismic Networklocated in Tenere, Gran Canaria, La Palma, El Hierro and Lanzarote have registered the magnitude . earthquake, which occurred between Tenere and Gran Canaria, at :: today.Friday January ,  that has been widely felt in Tenere and in some locations of Gran Canaria. title: theresa may brexit second referendum 2
story: No has told Europhile MPs a re-run of the Brexit vote couldnt come before .Its the first time Theresa Mays officials have admitted modelling how a second referendum could be delivered.The revelation came as the PM summoned senior politicians from across the parties for talks on how to break the Brexit deadlock.She asked civil servants to produce a briefing document explaining how long a second referendum would take.Anti-Brexit MPs were then given the paper in a bid to convince them that holding a fresh vote is effectively impossible.It states that Parliament would take seven months just to pass the legislation needed to lay the ground for a referendum, ITV News revealed.Then electoral watchdogs would spend  weeks ensuring the question is fair before the Commons and Lords can sign off on it.Finally, the campaign period itself must be at least  weeks long, and could take up to four months.That suggests the earliest date for a possible referendum would be March  - nearly a year after we are due to quit the EU.The timetable was blasted by pro-Remain Tory MP Phillip Lee, who said it was bulls**t and insisted a second referendum could be one in seven weeks.A No spokesman said: In order to inform the discussions a very short paper set out in factual detail the number of months which would be required.This was illustrative only and our position is of course that there will be no second referendum as the Prime Minister has repeatedly said.Ministers have previously denied making any preparations for a second referendum.Nigel Farage said today: My New Year resolution was to hope for the best but prepare for the worst, I am afraid that the worst is getting closer.

title: cheryl just too bolshoi the greatest dancer
story: Dance War, DanceX, Britannia High, So You Think You Can Dance, The Nation’s Favourite Dance Moments, Dance Your Ass Off, Got To Dance.Unfortunately, the living world is crammed full of TV executives who think viewers have the memory of a care-home goldfish.So there’s another one ready for the furnaces now on BBC.The Greatest Dancer, which began its run by proclaiming: “This is an audition and a studio like no other.”Instantly, then, you knew it was an audition show like every other created by Simon Cowell, with tears, journeys, backstage eccentrics and a mic’d up studio audience who can part the stage mirrors per cent of them vote for the dancer.A doddle, frankly, as this lot are suckers for a plucky underdog and a sob story.There’s also more than a hint of the familiar about the regulars, as we’ve got Alesha Dixon and Ashley Banjo’s brother Jordan hosting the show and three judges who, to give it the vaguest illusion of originality, have been re-branded as “dance captains”.One is Matthew Morrison off Glee and another is Strictly try-hard Oti Mabuse, who’s fast earning the nickname OTT Mabuse.All the money and attention, however, have clearly gone on “Cheryl”, who’s still above having a surname and is now also coming over like she’s Anna-bloody-Pavlova, boasting about her time at the Royal Balletand looking properly exasperated with the studio audience “who aren’t technically minded” enough for Her Ladyship’s liking.Every now and then we’ll also get to see one of the contestants, who are ­competing to win £, and “a slot on Strictly Come Dancing”, the size and scale of which will probably depend on the success of this series.So expect to catch the next glimpse of them mid-October, wheeling on ­Claudia Winkleman’s terms-and-conditions board.It should be a straightforward process of elimination, of course, as auditions have so far included “street”, “contemporary”, “freestyle”, “Afro-dance” and lots of other styles that could be placed under the same umbrella heading of “tw*tting about”.Strict rules of political correctness, though, muddy the waters.A partner or relative is allowed to plead on their behalf before they’ve even set foot on stage, meaning Rudolf Nureyev could turn up here, spin his ar*e off and still not get  per cent approval unless he was bullied at school or had a dead granny.Surprises, then, have so far been limited to one incredibly camp bedroom-dancer called James, ­represented by a woman who dropped every jaw in the theatre when she announced: “I’m his fiancée.”That was enough of a shock to send him swinging through to the next round.That’s just about your lot, though, as the rest of the series has moved with all the unpredictable thrill and dynamism of your tax s, even stopping at one point so Amelia, the reception desk flirt, could do a spot of dusting.If anything ever summed up the result of this grinding and predictable approach to light entertainment, it was the feel-good slogan behind a young Irish auditionee, called Fionn, on Saturday night.“Dance like nobody’s watching.”Good as done.Ten years of brilliant and brave Twitter hero Rachel Riley on Countdown.ITV’s Manhunt managing to survive the ­miscasting of Martin Clunes in the main role.And The Paras: Men Of War selection process proving every bit as brutal and unforgiving as you’d hope. So expect some politicians to miss the point entirely and make it more “inclusive”.ASKED to produce a list of the th Century’s most iconic explorers, everyone would probably name Scott of the Antarctic, Roald Amundsen, Edmund Hillary and Sherpa Tenzing Norgay.Everyone, that is, except a group of BBC “experts”, who ignored all of the above and replaced them with Jane Goodall and Gertrude Bell last week.I don’t even need to explain why, obviously.The names alone tell you it’s all down to the deranged, obsessive PC box-ticking that governs everything the BBC does and makes a farce of its new voting series Icons, which has the nerve to claim: “We want your opinion.”It doesn’t, obviously. It wants to impose the BBC’s right-on opinion on you and swallow its rewritten version of th Century history in the process.So for quota-driven reasons, Elvis didn’t make the entertainers shortlist and Alexander Fleming was left out of the last four scientists, despite discovering penicillin.But while Margaret Thatcher was included among the political finalists – and, boy, that must have hurt the BBC – they totally ignored her Falklands and Cold War victories in favour of re-styling her as a female gender warrior, almost the very last thing the former Prime Minister actually stood for.The episode where this series’ barmy levels of political correctness will really be laid bare is the Sports Stars episode, which has named Labour-supporting Paralympian Tanni Grey-Thompson as one of the th Century’s four greatest icons, but left out Jesse Owens, George Best, Usain Bolt, Rod Laver, Olga Korbut, Roger Federer, Eric Liddell, Martina Navratilova, Seb Coe, Jack Nicklaus, Tiger Woods, Carl Lewis, Diego Maradona, Michael Jordan, Ayrton Senna and even the talisman of our greatest trophy-winning team of all, Doug Rougvie.Shameful.This Morning’s Alison Hammond, , metres above sea level, in the ski resort of Val D’Isere, interviewing skiers ­wearing skiing gear: “Why are you here ”THE Voice UK contestant Dean Mac is living the dream. How do we know He told us all, on Saturday night.“I’m living the dream,” he boasted, “in a really cool penthouse apartment, in the centre of Manchester. Duplex, with a pool table.”He also told us he performed “baby-making music,” though the world had been surprisingly slow to acknowledge Dean’s “triple threat” potential.“I went to LA, Paris, Liverpool, as a choreographer dancer, and one day a music producer said, ‘You need to be the front guy’.“The next stage now is to release the beast of my showmanship and have my craft appreciated.”So, on Saturday, he unleashed it in the direction of the four Voice judges and, honestly, the reaction was almost perfect.Hardly a serious button flinch or a twitch or a hint one of them was going to bite. In fact, he’d have had more luck getting the four heads on Mount Rushmore to turn.A response that said: “If that’s baby-making music, the human race is gone in  years’ time.”The saving grace of the ITV show’s format is that there’s nothing he could do or say to the judges afterwards either.Dean Mac just had to trudge back to his “really cool penthouse apartment”.Living the dream.Chris Kamara: “He headed his shot just over the bar.”The food: “Pizza, pasta, ravioli and all that s***.”I know. Close your eyes and you could almost be there. And s***.Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “On a computer ­keyboard, the abbreviation PGDN is short for page what ”Gerry: “Up.”The Time It Takes, Joe Lycett: “Who wrote Handel’s Water Music ”Lindsey: “Pass.”The Chase, Bradley Walsh: “What name links a chocolate bar and a ship on which a mutiny occurred ”Lauren: “Cadbury.”And Ben Shephard: “In which century did the Second World War take place ”Vicky: “st.”An epidemic of head-tilting right-on morons telling us: “It takes a whole village to raise a child.”Loose Woman Gloria Hunnord conjuring up a horric mental image when she told ice-dancing Saira Khan: “I worry about you when the one-hand job comes in.”And Icons presenter Chris Packham boldly comparing himself to Marie Curie and Einstein with the observation: “I’m a bit of an outsider too.”Though, just so we can put their achievements in proper perspective, neither Marie Curie nor ­Einstein ever got their own episode of Celebrity Cash In The Attic.GOOD Morning Britain, Piers Morgan: “I believe in fat-shaming. We need people around us to say, ‘Hey, you’re chunking up a bit’.”.Hey . . .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: how brexiteers celebrated defeating theresa
story: NewsAnalysisHow Brexiteer Tories celebrated with champagne at Jacob Rees-Moggs £m mansionJacob Rees-Mogg celebrated with some of the  revolting MPs at his opulent home after inflicting the biggest Tory rebellion in historyShareCommentsByPippa Crerar:,  JAN NewsAnalysisJacob Rees-Mogg opening the door to guests on Tuesday night - who received a glass of champagne "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWithin hours of inflicting the biggest defeat in modern history on Tuesday night, hardline Brexiteers’ champagne corks were popping. Jacob Rees-Mogg invited leading Tory eurosceptics including Boris Johnson, David Davis and Iain Duncan Smith to a celebration party. Guests were greeted with a champagne flute at the door of the Tory MP’s pound million mansion just minutes from the House of Commons. The other side of Westminster, Theresa May was contemplating her humiliating defeat and steeling herself for another tumultous day ahead. Her strategy for surviving the no confidence vote was to make sure she didn’t take the fizz out of the Brexiteers champagne too early.   Instead, she waited until after the result was announced by her chief whip before inviting Jeremy Corbyn and other party leaders to talks. But before they even made it to the steps of Downing Street she had scuppered any attempts at compromise by ruling out a customs union. It is Labour’s biggest ask - and would infuriate hardline Brexiteers - but is also one of the few plan Bs that could command a majority in Parliament.  Instead - as the clock ticks ever close to crashing out of the EU without a deal - more stalemate beckons. Over the next few days the PM will try to win over the leaders of smaller parties and backbench Labour MPs. But her refusal to even countenance budging on her red lines suggests she is putting the Tory party ahead of the national interest. She has just four days to try to reach agreement. At that point the Government will have to table a fresh motion which - crucially - can be amended by MPs.   Parliament will take control of Brexit with a series of votes on their own alternatives. Pro-EU MPs are expected to demand the Government rules out a no deal, delays Brexit or holds a second referendum. Even though the votes would not be legally binding, it would be politically impossible for the PM to ignore them. With a softer - and delayed - Brexit looking the most likely outcome, perhaps the champagne should have been kept on ice.

title: theresa refuses compromise over brexit
story: NewsTheresa May refuses to compromise over Brexit deal as she holds crisis talksIt came as Jeremy Corbyn accused the PM of holding phoney negotiationsShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editorNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  JAN NewsMay met senior Westminster figures amid claims up to  Tory MPs will quitshe doesn’t rule out a no-deal "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May was last night accused of refusing to compromise, amid claims up to  Tory MPs will quitshe doesn’t rule out a no-deal. The Prime Minister met senior Westminster figures for Brexit crisis talks as she tries to thrash out a revamped deal she can take back to Parliament. But Jeremy Corbyn continued to boycott negotiations – and urged Labour MPs not to take part until the Government ruled out a no-deal departure. It comes as Tory MP Nick Boles prepares to table an amendment that would let backbenchers delay Brexit for nine months, potentially avoiding leaving with no deal.  He has claimed that around  ministers could quitConshyshyservative MPs are ordered to oppose the amendment, which would be voted for alongside Mrs May’s new plan on January . Mr Boles said: “A large single-digit-number of Cabinet ministers have told me they will not vote against the amendment.A larger number of up to  ministers outside Cabinet say they will resignthey are whipped to vote against the amendment.” Mrs May’s current Brexit deal suffered a crushing -vote defeat in Parliament on Tuesday. Among those who held talks with the PM yesterday were Tory MPs Owen Paterson, Iain Duncan Smith, Mark Francois, Steve Baker, and Former Brexit Secretary David Davis, members of the pro-Brexit European Research Group. Many other MPs who held crisis talks with ministers yesterday criticised the PM for not yielding to break the deadlock.Green MP Caroline Lucas said: “Sadly, these talks are coming far too late and there is no sign the Prime Minister is genuinely willing to compromise.”   Labour’s Hilary Benn, chair of the Commons Brexit Committee, said: “The Government has to rule out no-deal. The Prime Minister needs to change her red lines.” The PM’s spokesman responded: “Clearly, there are some areas we aren’t going to agree on. But the very purpose of the meetings is to find areas where there is some consensus to find a way forward.”No also denied suggestions that the UK could commit to a customs union with the EU – a key Labour demand that has split the Cabinet.Labour leader Mr Corbyn yesterday continued to rebuff Mrs May’s offer to negotiate.Speaking in Hastings, where he visited staff at Conquest Hospital, Mr Corbyn accused her of holding “phoney talks to run down the clock”.  He said:“ If you are serious about reaching a deal, then no deal must be ruled out. Labour is open to meaningful discussions.But following the decisive rejection of the Government’s deal by MPs, those cannot be on the basis of your existing red lines.” If Mrs May ruled out a no-deal exit, it could trigger resignations of hard Brexiteers in her top team. The PM shot down Mr Corbyn’s “impossible condition”.She said: “Do you really believe that, as well as declining to meet for talks yourself, it is right to ask your MPs not to seek a solution with the Government ” Former Labour PM Tony Blair also blasted Mr Corbyn.He said: “If, in a moment of national crisis, the Prime Minister asks the Leader of the Opposition to talk, of course he should.” Mrs May will spend the weekend at Chequers and will update the Commons on Monday. She has axed plans to attend the World Economic Forum in Switzerland next week. Meanwhile, Tory MP Boris Johnson will today make the latest in a series of thinly veiled leadership bids in a speech at a JCB plant in Staffordshire. He will say the Brexit vote was triggered by a feeling that the British people had been drting too far apart. “If we are to bring our nation together, that means investing in great public services and safer streets, better hospitals, transport links and housing.”

title: voice mirror its time lame
story: NewsopinionVoice of The Mirror: Its time lame PM got real and faced the truthTheresa May limps on… still in office but hardly in power as the Brexit shambles continues with no clear end in sightShareCommentsByVoice of the Mirror:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsopinionThe enfeebled Prime Minister is plainly not up to the task in hand "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThanks to the DUP, Theresa May limps on… still in office but hardly in power. It is the country’s misfortune that it faces its greatest crisis since the Second World War with an enfeebled Prime Minister who is plainly not up to the task in hand. Having suffered the worst defeat in shyParliamentary history, Mrs May finally did what she should have done when taking office – she reached out to opposition leaders.   Their reticence in accepting this belated olive branch is understandable. The PM has shown no indication she is prepared to compromise on her Brexit plans. Her appeal for MPs to act in the national interest would carry more weight had she not put her own party’s interest first at every stage. Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn was right to demand taking no-deal off the table as the condition for any talks. Mrs May must show she is ready to make concessions. If she is sincere about wanting progress, she also needs to start showing some humility and realism about her diminished authority.

title: family left devastated after boy
story: NewsFamily left devastated after boy, , was swept to death reveal joy at new babyLeanne and Darrel Fleck from County Antrim, Northern Ireland had their lives turned upside down when their son Kayden drowned in the Braid RiverShareCommentsByClaire OBoyle:,  JAN NewsJayden, Leanne, baby Ellieanna, Amelia and Darrel Fleck are to mark the heartbreaking milestone"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA family whose lives were shattered after their boy was swept to death in a river have spoke of their joy at the birth of a new baby. Leanne and Darrel Fleck are preparing to mark the year since their son Kayden died at the age of five. The mischievous and fun-loving schoolboy was swept to his death on the Braid River in County Antrim, Northern Ireland. His identical twin brother Jayden was the last person to see him alive after desperately trying to save him. The youngster grabbed at his siblings fingertips as the freezing cold water carried him away. As the family brace themselves for the heartbreaking milestone, an unexpected ray of light has given them the strength. Baby Ellianna, Kayden’s little sister has brought joy to the familys le during their dark time. “We didn’t know she was coming,” Leanne told Belfast Live. “But about three weeks after we lost Kayden, through all the pain and darkness of that time, we discovered I was pregnant.   “It was a huge shock. And more than anything, it was just so bittersweet because we were going through all the emotions of losing Kayden and trying to figure out what way our family was going to go from there. Then suddenly, she came along. “She shone a wee bit of light on our family. We had people telling us it was too soon for us to cope after losing Kayden - but then we had others offering us support as well, and they said she was our wee blessing. And I think she was. “I’m never going to forget Kayden. I’m never going to forget that day. And when the anniversary comes around I don’t know how we’re going to be but at least now we have our baby to focus on. “She’s healthy, she’s here, she’s our wee girl and we will love and care for her like we did Kayden, and our other children.” The morning of that fateful Saturday in February last year started out full of hope and fun. Leanne and Darrel, who had tied the knot just two weeks earlier with their handsome twins as ring bearers, had moved the family from the Ballykeel estate in Ballymena to a new home in Cullybackey with high hopes for the future. That day, they ed to their old house to collect the last of their things. “We got in the car, me and Darrel, the twins and our daughter Amelia, and headed back to Ballykeel,” said Leanne. “Darrel had to clear out the shed, and I wanted to make sure everything was out and that the place was clean and tidy before we handed the keys in.” And it is this detail, as well as every other twist and turn of that time which Leanne continues to pore over and use to torment herself.   “I just wonderwe hadn’t gone back to the house to clear up that day, orwe hadn’t decided to move to Cullybackey at all, would we have lost him ” said Leanne. “Darrel was out sorting the shed and I was in the sitting room when one of the boys came in and said, ‘Can we go out the back ’ Even now I can’t say for sure which of them it was, because I was taking down these old blinds and I just said, ‘OK, but don’t be going away’. “I didn’t even look round to see which one it was and I hate myself for that because I was too busy doing these bits and pieces to look around. “You see they never went anywhere without us. They never went far, and that day I thought they’d be running in and out through the empty house into the back garden but when I went out to put the blinds in the bin, they weren’t there.” When Darrel told Leanne the boys had been in the garden just seconds earlier, the pair headed straight to the boys’ usual stomping ground, a play-park just a stones throw from the house.  But the boys were not there. “Kayden had found p in the car on the way so my next thought was, had they tried to walk to the shop up from the house,” said Leanne.“So we split up to look for them. We didn’t even think to go to the river because they’d never been that direction without us in their lives.” It was Darrel who first became aware just how grave the situation was. He recalled: “I was looking for the boys and then I heard ‘Daddy help, Daddy help’, and there was Jayden coming running across the path. “He was soaked from his neck to his feet. I asked him where Kayden was and he said, ‘He fell in the river Daddy, he fell in the river’.” Young Jayden and his father rushed to the spot Kayden had fallen, at the edge of the Braid River near the Ecos Centre in Ballymena. “I was running up and down the river looking for Kayden, searching for the bright orange jumper he was wearing that day,” said Darrel. A man passing by heard the commotion, and called for help. “They were quick,” said Darrel. “But by the time the police and search and rescue were there, Kayden was long gone.” The schoolboy, a pupil at Harryville Primary School in Ballymena, was pulled from the river four miles away. “Afterwards, Jayden told us he was wet because he’d got into the river to try and catch Kayden,” said Darrel.   “He’d got the tip of his finger, but the current was too strong and he couldn’t hold onto him.” Making sense of the tragedy has been excruciating for the family. Why them and why that day  Why had one son managed to escape the river, while the other had not  “It was awful, we couldn’t make sense of it,” said Leanne, who also has an older son, Daniel, . “But Jayden said he held onto the grass, he clung to it. Kayden couldn’t.” While the boys were identical in almost every way, one huge dference marked the twins apart. From the moment he was born, Kayden was extremely ill. Born with a congenital heart defect, hypoplastic right heart syndrome, he spent the first year of his le in hospital, travelling from Belfast to Birmingham, to Antrim and back undergoing surgery and intensive treatment for his condition. The youngster didn’t step foot in his family home until two days before his first birthday. “We had the biggest party for them, we hired a hall and got them a clown,” recalled Leanne, smiling at the memory. “But that start in le meant Jayden was always that little bit stronger. Kayden had his first open heart surgery when he was  hours old, and the last one less than a year before he died. We’d hoped that one would see him through until he was .” Kayden’s tough start in le only strengthened his bond with his brother, and little Jayden was his right-hand man through it all. “Kayden was taken straight to Birmingham Children’s Hospital the day after he was born,” said Darrel. “Leanne wasn’t allowed to fly because she’d had a caesarean, but I went over with my mum. “On the fourth day, I was able to come back and take Jayden over with me on the flight and when the boys were about a week old a nurse asked meJayden had been in beside his brother yet.   “When I told her no, she took Jayden and set him into the cot beside his brother. Their two wee arms came together, and they held hands. That’s when Kayden started to turn a corner.” After that, says Leanne, the boys were inseparable. And when their sister Amelia came along less than two years later, she got stuck straight in. “She was joined at the hip with Kayden as well,” said Leanne. “Now she says a prayer to him every night when she goes to bed. Even though he was just a toddler when she was born, he loved babies. He’d have loved Ellianna.” And the family are determined the baby, now seven weeks old, will grow up knowing all about her brother.  “I said from day one, from the minute we lost him that he’s always going to be part of our family,” said Leanne. “So we will make sure she knows him.” Complications from Ellianna’s birth meant Leanne spent three days in hospital in the run-up to Christmas, only getting home to her family on Christmas morning. “On the way home, Darrel and me took a drive over to the grave,” she said. “It was hard, knowing Kayden wasn’t there to share it all - the joy of the baby, the joy of Christmas with his family. That’s the hardest part. “People have said to me they find it hard I’m still talking about him after nearly a year, but that’s my way of coping. I talk about him constantly,I’m here by myself I’ll talk to his pictures. If he’s gone five years or , I’ll still talk about him and to him because to me he is still here. “And even though we can’t see him and we can’t hear him he’s going to live on in us, and in the other wee ones. Ellianna will know him. He’s her big brother.” Following the tragedy, the family have called for safety steps around the Braid River to be stepped up. “I just want to make sure this doesnt happen to any other family,” said Leanne. A Mid and East Antrim Borough Council spokesperson said: “Council has erected new barriers and signage along sections of the River Braid. A full water safety survey has also been conducted across Mid and East Antrim’s water sites. Staff regularly inspect paths along river banks to monitor flooding and slippage. “We would urge anyone using paths near rivers to be aware of potential flooding, particularly during heavy rainfall. Council are also launching a water safety campaign later this year to help raise awareness of the dangers of water.”

title: one place prince philip cant
story: NewsOne place where Prince Philip cant be arrested - no matter what he doesThe Queen is immune from being arrested but it appears that the rest of her family dont have the same luxuryShareCommentsByCourtney PochinAudience Writer:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsThe Duke of Edinburgh was involved in a nasty crash "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAs Norfolk police investigate a collision involving Prince Philips Land Rover and another vehicle at Babingley, there are some pressing questions that spring to mind. The first - Is the Duke of Edinburgh alright  The second - Can members of the Royal Family even be arrested by the police  Well the answer to the first is thankfully a very good one, as Buckingham Palace have confirmed that he was not injured in the accident. However, the answer to the other question is a little more complicated.   Its well known that The Queen has Sovereign Immunity in the UK, meaning that she can, quite literally, do no wrong. No civil or criminal proceedings can be taken against the Sovereign, but the same rule doesnt apply to any other member of the Royal Family. Therefore, it is the case that the likes of Prince Philip, Prince Charles, Prince William and Meghan Markle can be arrested - however there are a few loopholes. According to the legal encyclopedia, Halsburys Laws of England, members of the Royal Household cannot be arrested in civil proceedings.   Moreover, theres one very specic place that offers them protection. The encyclopedia states that arrests cannot take place in the presence of the monarch - so as long as they stay by the Queens side, they cant be cuffed by a police officer. This rule also applies to the ious royal palaces across Britain, such as Buckingham Palace and Kensington Palace. If a royal is anywhere near a palace, they cannot be taken into police custody.   One royal has already been given a criminal conviction. In , the Princess Royal,Princess Annewas fined pound and made to pay compensation after pleading guilty to a charge of one of her dogs attacking children. She was the first member of the royal family to plead guilty to a criminal offence. The year before this, Anne was also fined pound for speeding in her Bentley after admitting driving at mph in a mph zone in Gloucestershire.

This afternoon Prince Philip was behind the wheel of a Land Rover which overturned after being in a collision near the Queens Sandringham Estate in Norfolk. The -year-old, who was miraculously unharmed, was breath tested at the scene by a Norfolk Police officer and provided a negative reading. Some have questioned the fact the Duke of Edinburgh was still driving, despite his advanced age. On June   Prince Charles told a D-Day veterans son he worried about his dads insistence on still driving a car. The heir-to-the-throne spoke to Ivor Thomas, a former Corporal in the Royal Engineers. Mr Thomass son, Philip told the Prince his father, who was sitting in a wheelchair, still insisted on driving his car, a  Ford Sierra.   So does my father. Im always worried, Charles said, before gesturing towards Mr Thomas, and asking: But his eyesights all right  These apparent concerns did not dissuade the duke from driving Barrack and Michelle Obama to lunch during their visit in April . And earlier last year he was pictured driving at the Royal Windsor Horse Show.The cause of the accident is under investigation, Norfolk Police said.The president of the AA, Edmund King said high profile car crashes involving elderly drivers often spark calls for bans or restrictions on older drivers.   But he added: If driving restrictions based on age and safety were introduced we would be more likely to restrict young drivers rather than older drivers. Young, predominantly male, drivers are much more likely to crash within six months of passing their test than older drivers within six months of hanging up their keys. Older drivers often self restrict their driving by not driving at night and only driving on familiar roads. Norfolk Police said it was force policy to breath test all drivers involved in collisions.   Although the duke and the passenger in the Land Rover, thought to be a close protection officer, were unharmed two women in the other vehicle, a Kia, suffered minor injuries. They have both since been discharged from hospital. The duke is spending the evening at Sandringham with the Queen at his side. title: prince philip closely monitored doctors
story: NewsPrince Philip will be closely monitored by doctors amid fears of deadly bleed on brain riskIt is possible he will suffer delayed symptoms from his car crashShareByPaul ByrneLouie SmithMartin BagotAmy Coles:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsPrince Philip was behind the wheel of the overturned car, Buckingham Palace confirmed"Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPrince Philip will be closely monitored by doctors in the coming days as they look for signs of internal injuries. Medics fear the prince could be at risk of a subdural haematoma, a bleed on the brain, which can be deadly. Dr Nick Scriven, President of the Society for Acute Medicine, said yesterday: “They will have to keep an eye on him overnight because the risk for this will be over the next  to  hours.” The prince emerged shaken but seemingly physically unscathed from the collision. But Dr Scriven said: “This is not a minor event for a -year-old.” Philip was seen immediately by a doctor at the Sandringham Estate and it was decided he did not need treatment at hospital. But it is possible he will suffer delayed symptoms and experts say because of his age, an accident of this type could have serious consequences.   Dr Scriven said: “Risks in any accident like this are concussion or even a subdural haematoma following a head injury.” A subdural haematoma is where blood collects between the skull and the surface of the brain. Dr Scriven added: “This would especially be a worry in the elderly. If he has had any head injury he will need monitoring for his mental state and alertness. People suffering from subdural haematoma can become confused and sleepy. “He will have people around him I suspect. He may have medical staff who will be with him. If he wasn’t knocked out and there’s no obvious head trauma it is probably OK for him to stay at home and be monitored by the people who know him.”  Subdural haematomas are potentially deadly and can cause seizures, coma, behavioural changes, headaches or vomiting. Dr Scriven said the prince’s age makes it likely that he will take time to bounce back after the “trauma” of the crash. He said : “It doesn’t take much trauma for a very elderly person to lose their confidence. “If he is immobile with bruises it will take a while to regain his strength and fitness because people who are immobile lose their fitness very quickly. “The loss of mobility for a couple of days can take two or three weeks to get back. Then there are risks of infection to any elderly person who is immobile, especiallythey are in pain.”  Ella Clarke-Billings, an AE nurse at King’s College, said: “He could have had an internal bleed, head injuries and whiplash. It depends whether he was wearing a seat belt. If the air-bag was deployed, he could have suffered broken or fractured bones. “Obviously with a person of that age, the recovery times are slower. The stress of the crash would also have more of an impact at that age. They would be more confused, or reach a state they call delirium.” The Duke of Edinburgh has stayed fit and sprightly despite his advancing years. He still insists on walking upstairs when possible, but has faced some health problems, needing hip surgery and suffering repeated bladder infections.   Since his retirement from official solo duties in , he has appeared in public alongside the Queen and other members of the royal family at events and church services. After bowing out of public le Philip was expected to keep busy with his hobbies, including carriage driving, oil painting and bird watching. In November , he and the Queen marked  years of marriage, their platinum anniversary, with a black-tie dinner at Windsor Castle. While Philip attended the Cenotaph remembrance service and the traditional Christmas church service at Sandringham in , he was absent from both events last year. In April  he spent a week-and-a-half in hospital after his hip replacement operation.  Just a month later he attended the wedding of grandson Prince Harry and Meghan Markle . In October  he watched granddaughter Princess Eugenie wed Jack Brooksbank. The Duke of Edinburgh admitted ahead of his th birthday in  that he wanted “less responsibility, less rushing about”. In a BBC interview, Prince Philip said: “I reckon I’ve done my bit, I want to enjoy myself for a bit now. “With less responsibility, less rushing about, less preparation, less trying to think of something to say. “On top of that your memory’s going, I can’t remember names. “Yes, I’m just sort of winding down.”

On self belief...It turns out Winnie-the-Pooh was surprisingly good with motivational messages to make you go after your dreams.Just look at these encouraging snippets to help you reach your ambitions: “You are braver than you believe, stronger than you seem, and smarter than you think.” “Never let things come to you, go out and fetch them.” “Never stop dreaming.”   And how’s this for a lesson in knowing your own strengths and weaknesses  “I wish I could jump like that. But some can and some can’t. That’s how it is.” But remember: “It’s best to know what you’re looking for, before you look for it.” On missed goals mistakes He also knew not to get to down when things don’t go your way... “Rivers know this: there is no hurry. We shall get there some day.” “My spelling is Wobbly. It’s good spelling but it Wobbles, and the letters get in the wrong places.” On trust and friendship... Lovable Pooh’s quotes on fun and friendship could have a book of their own... “We didn’t realise we were making memories. We just knew we were having fun.”   “A day without a friend is like a pot without a single drop of honey left inside.” And before getting annoyed at a friend, maybe consider this... “If the person you are talking to doesn’t appear to be listening, be patient. It may simply be that he has a small piece of fluff in his ear.” On love and dating...And when it comes to love Pooh knows it’s the little moments that really count the most. And who can disagree with that sentiment “A hug is always the right size.” “If there ever comes a day when we can’t be together, keep me in your heart, I’ll stay there forever.” On the importance of doing nothing...While ambition is important, Pooh knew we also have to stop and take it slow oncein a while to really appreciate le...“Don’t underestimate the value of Doing Nothing, of just going along, listening to all the things you can’t hear, and not bothering.” “People say nothing is shyimpossible, but I do nothing every day.”  On looking after your body... Sleepy Pooh only had two speed settings, dead slow and stop. But he was aware of the need to look after yourself – whether that means working out... or just chilling out. “A bear, however hard he tries, grows tubby without exercise.” On coping with loss... “How lucky I am to have shysomething that makes saying goodbye so hard.” On treating everyone how you would want to be treated... Pooh was proud to be short and fat – but he would not have stood for any body-shaming.... “Just because an animal is large, it doesn’t mean he doesn’t want kindness.”

title: girl 15 whos allergic everything
story: NewsGirl, , whos allergic to everything could be killed by a strong smellTwo-and-a-half years ago Martina Baker was a healthy child, but overnight she was suddenly overcome with horrying symptomsShareCommentsByIsla HarveyLuke Kenton:,  JAN NewsMartina Baker suffers from an extremely rare disease that makes her allergic to almost anything "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA -year-old girl suffering from a rare disease could be killed by a strong smell, her family have revealed. Martina Baker, from Maine, USA, sufferers from Mast Cell Activation Syndrome- an immunological condition that makes her allergic to “almost anything”, including heat, water and perfume. Even a whf of cooking oil or bleach could send the teenager into anaphylactic shock, andtreatment isn’t administered right away Martina could die. She’s also highly allergic to marijuana smoke, which poses a dficult issue for the teen, as the drug was recently legalised in her home state.   But now, after raising , , there’s a new hope for Martina as her family have been able to get her a highly-trained assistance dog who could help to save her le. With Caiomhe at her side, Martina was recently able to sit though a movie at a cinema for the first time in years - giving her a new lease of le.   Caiomhe has changed my le, I feel so much safer with her around, I am able to have a social le again, said Martina, who was forced to miss school and stay at home in a sealed room to avoid anaphylactic shocks. I lost a lot of friends after I developed MCAS, its hard for people to handle, for them to watch me collapse and have to take my EpiPen and be rushed to hospital all the time, added Martina, who lives in Wiscasset. It could be very lonely at times, but Caiomhe is always beside me protecting me, shes a best friend for sure. She makes me feel less alone, she even checks up on me in the middle of the night.”  Until two and a half years ago Martina was completely healthy, but overnight she was suddenly overcome by terrying symptoms. I wasnt allergic to anything before, then one day I woke up with hives all over my body. I had to go to the hospital because I had an anaphylactic reaction. My throat started swelling up with hives. They treated me with an EpiPen. The students problems only intensied from there. The hives would flare up all the time, shed go into anaphylactic shock and wed to have to rush her to the ER about three times a week, said Martinas mother Loretta Morse Leighton, , a family therapist. We never knew what was triggering it really.” Last summer a skunk sprayed off outside Martinas bedroom window, she went into anaphylactic shock and had to be rushed to AE. Afterwards she had to go and live with a friend for almost two weeks while we had her bedroom windows and door completely sealed up, it was awful, recalled Loretta.  For months doctors had been baffled by Martinas condition. We took her to see a specialist in every major discipline, everything from cardiologists to psychologists, said Loretta, who eventually took Martina to an immunologist in Massachusetts named Jonathan Bayuk, who correctly diagnosed her with MCAS. Thanks to Caiomhe and regular mast cell stabilizing drugs Martinas anaphylactic episodes have reduced from three times a week to once every four to six weeks. Martina often wears a mask when she goes outside and the family still has to be very careful in their home. Loretta cleans with vinegar instead of cleaning products and has stopped using all detergents on sheets and clothing. They must practice odorless cooking and spend a lot of time grilling outside, even in winter. Martina is extremely sensitive to warmth, so her bedroom isnt heated at all, even during the freezing Maine winters.  I dont know how she tolerates the cold, she lives like a penguin in there, laughed Loretta. Last year Loretta discovered that a service dog might help her daughter. Caiomhe was trained by Jamie Robinson, a specialist in Tucson, Arizona - one of the only people in the world to train dogs to assist MCAS patients. Jamie trained Caiomhe to identy a long list of smells that are le-le-threatening triggers for Martina. A dogs nose is about , times better than a human nose and just about every biochemical process in our bodies is indicated with a change in scent, said Jamie, , who runs her own service dog business called Access to Service Corp.  Jamie had Martina send her pieces of clothing she had worn so Caiomhe could get used to her scent, including when she was in anaphylaxis because, to a dog, that scent is dferent. Caiomhe can now snf out when Martina is having a reaction before Martina realizes it, because she can smell the release of histamine from her body. Martina and three-year-old Caiomhe were first united on January  and have been inseparable ever since. Martina has endured a lot of staring, pointing and rude remarks etc, people do not understand, its very dficult for her but shes stayed extremely strong, Im so proud of her, said Loretta. I feel that Caiomhe was destined to be my daughtersangel. In the pictures of Martina now with Caiomhe, I see joy, light and le. A spark that has been missing and robbed from her since this awful disease has taken ahold of her. Caiomhe brought that back to her in a new, wonderful and amazing way.” From more information on MCAS visit: https:tmsforacure.org symptoms symptoms-and-triggers-of-mast-cell-activation

story: NewsDad finds secret cameras in Airbnb rental - but is told he consented to itJeffrey Bigham found one camera in the living room of the property and another near the bathroom doorShareCommentsByLuke Kenton:,  JAN NewsJeff Bigham had been staying at the property with his family during a winter break "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA dad-of-three discovered two hidden cameras inside his Airbnb apartment - with one allegedly positioned facing the bathroom door.
